comments.body:
> Not an objection, but just a comment that I try to be very sparing with bold, italics, etc. It gets out of hand pretty easily.

Ack. I felt this is a point worth emphasising both to Collaborators, and to contributors who read this (as on most screens it appears above the fold)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +25,29 @@## Issues and Pull Requests

Courtesy should **always** be shown to individuals submitting issues and pull
requests to the Node.js project. Be welcoming to first time contributors,
identified by the GitHub ![badge](./doc/first_timer_badge.png) badge.

comments.body: It would be better if we include the cases listed by @targos and in https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/17332#issuecomment-347463150 here.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +128,132 @@  `code-and-learn` and `good-first-issue` pull requests typically fall
  into this category.
* Changes that fix regressions.

When a pull request is deemed suitable to be fast-tracked, label it with

comments.body: Technically, that would only be necessary if Windows or Raspberry Pi weren't green in the previous run, right? But I don't know if that is worth documenting. We probably only need to get so specific....
Oh, wait, @addaleax already raised this point and @richardlau already responded.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +190,194 @@everything else. Start a fresh CI if more than seven days have elapsed since
the original failing CI as the compiled binaries for the Windows and ARM
platforms are only kept for seven days.

Some of the CI Jobs may require `GIT_REMOTE_REF` which is the remote portion
